awd_titl_txt: Project MAPS: Mapping Non-Response to Math Interventions
awd_abstract_narration:
Students who perform poorly in mathematics early in school are at risk for continuing to struggle in mathematics throughout elementary school and beyond. Recent empirical studies of targeted interventions for students at-risk in mathematics indicate overall effectiveness at positively impacting student outcomes. However, a subset of students fail to exhibit a positive response to generally efficacious intervention programs. To date limited research has investigated the behavioral, cognitive, and neural mechanisms underlying non-response to such mathematics interventions. 

The goal of this project is to identify patterns of performance on critical mathematics constructs, their underlying neural signatures, and achievement outcomes for on-track learners, at-risk controls, responders, and non-responders within the context of a randomized control trial of a research-validated first grade math intervention. The work will extend beyond examining specific regions of the brain in isolation to an approach that examines functional connectivity across regions. The project will investigate changes in functional connectivity in concert with behavioral measures to facilitate an in depth exploration of critical early math processes and the behavioral and neural indicators thereof. Findings from the work will be utilized to generate hypotheses on critical math constructs as potential targets for supplemental intervention components to improve intervention outcomes for non-responders. Coupling neuroimaging and school-based intervention research in an early mathematics context represents a unique contribution to the field of mathematics development and the broad array of constructs examined may offer insights into the interaction of mathematics development with other neurological disorders including dyslexia. 

This project is supported by NSF's EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development. The program supports the accumulation of robust evidence to inform efforts to understand, build theory to explain, and suggest intervention and innovations to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning and participation.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
In Mapping Non-Response to Math Intervention (Project MAPS) our research team worked with first grade students with difficulties in mathematics to explore brain and behavior changes related to math learning. The primary aim of Project MAPS was to better understand how and why math intervention works for some and not for others. We collected math achievement data, measures of cognitive skills, and resting state neuroimaging data to identify indicators of math learning that can be leveraged by researchers and curriculum developers to improve math instruction. In all, we collected pre-post neuroimaging data for 189 first-grade students, 117 with math difficulties and 72 typically achieving students. The first two years of Project MAPS were conducted in concert with a large-scale intervention study where struggling students were randomly assigned to a first-grade math intervention or control. In the latter years, our team worked with local schools and community partners to recruit participants. As a result, we compiled a rich dataset with diverse participants identified for study participation via school-based performance.

Importantly, Project MAPS collected resting state data to measure connections between various parts of the brain as opposed to brain activation data, which measures parts of the brain that are active when doing particular tasks. Collecting resting state neuroimaging data with first-grade students posed several logistical challenges because subjects need to stay very still during the MRI process. As a result, an important contribution of this work is our publication detailing the data acquisition and cleaning process we used in Project MAPS (see Smith et al., 2023) to maximize data quality and quantity. In addition to describing the full data processing procedure for our data, this publication describes a process that can be replicated by other neuroimaging researchers to reduce data loss when working with young children.     

By collecting resting state data in combination with math achievement data, we hope to better understand how young brains are developing in a holistic sense in response to school-based math instruction and intervention. Preliminary analyses of resting state data indicate that there may be some differences in brain connectivity for students with math difficulties compared to typically achieving students. Analyses conducted with math achievement data showed a relationship between symbolic number skills and the accuracy of quantity comparisons for first grade students. Future analyses are planned to examine how changes in math skill are associated with changes in brain connectivity over time and the role of cognitive skills in this association. Ultimately, findings from Project MAPS will be used to identify patterns of performance related to math learning that can inform future research and school-based screening and math instruction practices.


Last Modified: 02/29/2024
Modified by: Benjamin S Clarke
